greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Array read by antidiagonals: a(n,k) = number of k-colorings of a circle of n nodes (n >= 1, k >= 1).
comment: Note that we keep one edge in the circular graph even when there's only one node (so there are 0 colorings of one node with k colors).
Number of closed walks of length n on the complete graph K_{k}. - _Andrew Howroyd_, Mar 12 2017
link: Andrew Howroyd, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..1274
example: a(4,3) = 18 because there are three choices for the first node's color (call it 1) and then two choices for the second node's color (call it 2) and then the remaining two nodes can be 12, 13, or 32. So in total there are 3*2*3 = 18 ways. a(3,4) = 4*3*2 = 24 because the three nodes must be three distinct colors.
xref: Columns include A092297, A226493. Main diagonal is A118537.
results.author: _Joshua Zucker_, May 29 2005
